title: Scroll predominant axis only (prevents scroll drift)

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
This is a fix for #62003.
This fixes a UX problem that's easy to observe when using a trackpad, particularly on a MacBook:
It's almost impossible to scroll purely vertically, so on files with long lines a horizontal drift can occur which means the first few character columns might drift under the gutter even when the scroll intent was purely vertical.

This PR adds a boolean to the editor configuration (`editor.scrollPredominantAxisOnly`). When enabled it scrolls only the predominant axis. This prevents unintentional scroll drift, i.e. slightly diagonal scrolling when scrolling only one axis was intended.

Furthermore, I propose this to be the new default since for almost all software that presents text (or code) this is the standard behavior. The current behavior is standard only in graphic-centric applications where moving diagonally is intended more often.

title: VoiceOver on mac does not read new lines inside of Visual Studio Code editor
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.32.1
- OS Version: macOS Mojave 10.14.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Turn VoiceOver on by pressing: command F5.
2. Launch Visual Studio Code
3. Open a file which contains some code or write a method or two.
4. Make sure to interact with the text area by pressing: ctrl option shift down arrow.
5. Now, navigate through the text with up or down arrow and listen what VoiceOver reads.

Expected result:
When the voiceOver encounters a new line, it should read "new line"

Actual result:
When voiceOver encounters a new line, it does not read "new line" it actually repeats the last line that was not empty. Also, it often starts to read the whole content of the file.

To get a better feeling of how it should behave, open a TextEdit or Xcode and repeat the steps above. In TextEdit or Xcode, the VoiceOver reads "new line" when ever it comes across a new line.

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No
Yes

title: Extension contributes settings don't take effect until vscode restarted now

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version:1.32
- OS Version: mac/windows

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Get an extension that has the html customData contributes setting for html tag lookups:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/68554
Download: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/2857364/svg-0.0.1.vsix.zip
2. Install in 1.32.
Notice the message says it installed fine.  In 1.31 it would say click "reload".
3. Open up an html file
4. Type <foreign  .  It should have offered you <foreignObject> but nothing happens.  The html editor's customData setting from the extension's contributes isn't working.  
5. Restart VSCode.
6. Repeat.  It works.

This is a regression in behavior from 1.31.  In 1.31, after installation of a vsix file, you would click on "Reload" button in message, and the settings would take effect.  Even doing a disable/enable on the extension doesn't work, you have to restart VSCode. 1.31 was much nicer, that you didn't have to do that.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

title: Cursor not displaying over correct position
body:
Issue Type: Bug Sometimes, my cursor, and any text highlights, aren't displayed in the correct position horizontally. I usually edit at zoom level 0 (default), and in that case the cursor may sometimes display to the right of where it should be. If I use Ctrl+- to go down to level -1, the issue goes away. I can't reliably reproduce this issue, it seems to happen randomly after a period of time, possibly related to monitors being plugged+unplugged and that changing DPI settings? It seems to match the issue described in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/26151, but that issue seems to have been solved. It references a 'disableMonospaceOptimizations' setting, but that setting seems to no longer exist? My fontsize is 12 and my font family is default (Consolas, 'Courier New', monospace) VS Code version: Code 1.31.1 (1b8e8302e405050205e69b59abb3559592bb9e60, 2019-02-12T02:20:54.427Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.16299

title: Emojis and double byte characters handling incorrect
body:
Issue Type: Bug 1. Insert US flag emoji (🇺🇸) 2. Move left once (left arrow) 3. Delete (or backspace) 4. Flag disappears, but only part of the encoding pair is removed and you can see the rest in the editor (e.g. 🇸) This is counter-intuitive (as well as different from all other editors). It also affects selecting text, clipboard operations and in case of editing can distort nearby characters. Possibly related to: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/34497 Thanks guys! VS Code version: VSCodium 1.31.1 (1b8e8302e405050205e69b59abb3559592bb9e60, 2019-02-13T17:56:31.816Z) OS version: Darwin x64 16.7.0

title: Opened files not restored after update
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Also please test using the latest insiders build to make sure your issue has not already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.31.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 1803 17134,590

Steps to Reproduce:

1. VSCode displays a toast prompting for update
2. Click on install update button
3. Update completes and VSCode restarts

Expected behavior:
All opened files are restored

Actual behavior:
None of the opened files are restored. Only the Welcome tab and the Release Notes tab are opened

This behavior is problematic as it adds a barrier to frequent updates. As a user, I am more reluctant to accept updates knowing that doing so might close all the files I'm currently working on or am keeping open for reasons. For instance, on a large projects with a complex directory structure, I keep files open to have them handy for an upcoming task.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

title: [themes] [syntax highlighting] allow theme to change font size, line height, negative indent
body:
## What

Code should allow custom themes to
- specify `font-size`, `line-height`, `text-variant` and etc. for every line
- specify `font-size`, `font-stretch` and etc. for inline elements

## Why

When you write markdown in current's VS code, the h1-h6 lines are the same size as the body text. This is not very helpful in terms of writing.

This is editing Markdown in Code (for now):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10850402/53856207-a0630900-3f96-11e9-831f-c9cbcf688ce8.png)

note that the title is less prominent than the bold text.

In contrast, this is editing Markdown in Bear:

[![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10850402/53855544-b3c0a500-3f93-11e9-9457-6aaa094c026e.png)](https://bear.app/#features)

We also need to resolve #20652 for this to work.

title: Terminals: hasChildProcesses should not run sync
body: We typically stay away from sync node API which blocks the renderer from executing and use async instead. Please check if [`hasChildProcesses`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/bf9a27e/src/vs/workbench/contrib/debug/node/terminals.ts#L260) really needs to be async or if callers already run in a promise context.

body: It seems like that in the latest insider builds the hover width has changed and now it can be wider than 500px. This is an attempt to fix this in hover.css

title: History of previous searched text for files
body:
It would be great if we could get remember texts which are used while searching for a file(**command + P** in mac) like ATOM editor.
In atom after searching for a file and selecting the appropriate file will be opened when we again do search for file (command + P in mac) we can select the previously searched file by pressing  **command + z** in  ATOM editor It would be awesome if we have the same feature in VS code as well

title: Add context to find if list item is collapsible

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Trying to bind <kbd>Space</kbd> to do 2 things:

* If the item is 📂 - toggle the folder `list.toggleExpand`
* If the item is not a folder - behave like <kbd>Enter</kbd> `list.select`

I was able to do this for the `Explorer`:
```json
{
	"key": "space",
	"command": "list.toggleExpand",
	"when": "explorerViewletFocus && explorerResourceIsFolder"
},
{
	"key": "space",
	"command": "list.select",
	"when": "explorerViewletFocus && !explorerResourceIsFolder"
},
```

However, I see no way to do that for `breadcrumbs`, Custom Views ...

title: Copy value please specify the context.
body:
https://github.com/Microsoft/debug-adapter-protocol/blob/gh-pages/debugAdapterProtocol.json#L1964-L1973

The copy value is implemented using EvaluateRequest. But now `context` is null. If VSCode can provide an enum for the copy value, the DA will be able to optimize it.

title: Diff editor shows that (almost) entire file has changed when it's not

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
Issue Type: Bug Doesn't always reproduce, but i've found a file where it bugs out. Steps to reproduce: 1. Create a new Git repo: `git init` 2. Commit file from https://unicode.org/Public/UCA/11.0.0/allkeys.txt 3. Replace the same file with version 12.0.0: https://unicode.org/Public/UCA/12.0.0/allkeys.txt 4. Open directory with this Git repo in vscode ("File: Open Folder") 5. In sidebar select "Source control" and open diff editor Result: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/993454/53710655-0e98b600-3e47-11e9-9b64-19db6d044a39.png) 6. Execute `git diff` in terminal (or Git Bash) ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/993454/53710711-39830a00-3e47-11e9-859e-0e013f5d9885.png) IMO output of `git diff` is more informative about what changes were made to this file between versions. I've seen diff results like that before on other files (actual source code). I've also prepared Git repository where issue reproduces so steps 1-3 can be skipped: [repro.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/2924332/repro.zip) VS Code version: Code 1.29.1 (bc24f98b5f70467bc689abf41cc5550ca637088e, 2018-11-15T19:07:43.495Z) OS version: Linux x64 4.4.0-142-generic
Extensions (5) Extension|Author (truncated)|Version ---|---|--- cpptools|ms-|0.19.0 shader|sle|1.1.4 vscode-lua|tri|0.12.4 cmake|twx|0.0.17 vscode-todo-highlight|way|1.0.4 (1 theme extensions excluded)
